facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 325 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 325 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September

facts.text: Appeal is from the Award dated September 20, 1963 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference CG IT-25 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 20, 1963 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference CG IT-25 of 1962. V. Gupte, Solicitor-

facts.text: Reference made by the Government of India under s. 10(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: delivered by Hidayatullah J. This is an appeal by special leave against an award dated September 20, 1963 made by the Presiding Officer of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in a reference made by the Government of India under s. 10(2)

facts.text: Appellants are the workmen of the Bombay Port Trust, represented by the Bombay Port Trust Employees Union.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the workmen of the Bombay Port Trust, who are and have been represented in this dispute by the Bombay Port Trust Employees Union. The respondents to this appeal are the trustees of the Port of Bombay.

facts.text: Respondents are the trustees of the Port of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to this appeal are the trustees of the Port of Bombay. The reference was made on a joint application of the parties.

facts.text: Reference made on a joint application of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was made on a joint application of the parties. and the matter in dispute was stated to be Whether the existing system of work of the shore crew of the Princes and Victoria Docks under which each shift

facts.text: Matter in dispute: Whether the existing system of work of the shore crew of the Princes and Victoria Docks under which each shift consists of 8 hours normal duty, 2 hours variable recess and 2 hours overtime needs any modification.

anchor.surface_text: and the matter in dispute was stated to be Whether the existing system of work of the shore crew of the Princes and Victoria Docks under which each shift consists of 8 hours normal duty, 2 hours variable recess and 12 hours overtime needs any modification?

facts.text: Tribunal held that the Union was not able to establish that the existing system of work needed any modification.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, by the award impugned here, held that the Union was not able to establish that the existing system of work needed any modification.

facts.text: Trustees first introduced a two shift system in the Alexandra Docks on June 30, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts appearing on the record it appears that the Trustees first introduced a two shift system of work in the Alexandra Docks on June 30, 1953 and the same system was extended to the Princes and Victoria Docks on December 15, 1953.

facts.text: Two shift system extended to Princes and Victoria Docks on December 15, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953 and the same system was extended to the Princes and Victoria Docks on December 15, 1953. Previously, the shore crew at all these places worked in a single shift and were liable to be called out at any hour of the day or night.

facts.text: Previously, shore crew worked in a single shift liable to be called out at any hour.

anchor.surface_text: Previously, the shore crew at all these places worked in a single shift and were liable to be called out at any hour of the day or night. When the two shift system began, each shift of 12 hours was broken up into 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable recess and 2 hours overtime.

facts.text: Each shift of 12 hours broken up into 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable recess and 2 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: When the two shift system began, each shift of 12 hours was broken up into 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable recess and 2 hours overtime. The hours of rest were kept variable as they depended on the tides.

facts.text: In 1956, workmen represented by Port Trust General Workers Union demanded fixed recess of two hours.

anchor.surface_text: In 1956 the workmen, who were then represented by the Port Trust General Workers Union, made a demand for a fixed recess of two hours. The Trustees apprehended that this was a device to get 4 hours overtime and rejected the demand.

facts.text: Trustees rejected the demand for fixed recess in 1956, threatened three-shift system.

anchor.surface_text: The Trustees apprehended that this was a device to get 4 hours overtime and rejected the demand. The General Workers Union was informed that if the demand was pressed a three-shift system would be introduced.

facts.text: Port Trust gave notice under s. 9A of Industrial Disputes Act on June 25, 1960 announcing introduction of variable recess at Alexandra Docks.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen at the Alexandra Docks seemed to have accepted a variable recess of two hours but the Port Trust gave a notice under s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act on June 25, 1960 announcing the introduction of variable recess although in the months other than the monsoon months recess was actually at fixed hours.

facts.text: At Alexandra Docks, shore crew work 8 hours duty, 1 hour variable recess, 3 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: The Trustees, therefore, resolved that the shore crew at the Alexandra Docks should work for 8 hours and that there should be a variable recess of one hour and overtime of three hours should be paid. Thus the 12 hours shift at the Alexandra Docks was 8 hours of duty, 3 hours overtime and one hour variable recess.

facts.text: At Princes and Victoria Docks and Butcher Island: 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable rest, 2 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: This system was, however, not extended to the princes and Victoria Docks and Butcher Island. At these docks 8 hours duty, 2 hours rest at variable times and 2 hours overtime were prescribed.

facts.text: Union contended that the division of 12 hours shift into 8 hours work, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime violated Minimum Wages Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Union contended that this division of 12 hours shift into 8 hours work, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime violated the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and that the so-called period of rest was illusory since, being variable, it was some times given right at the commencement of the shift and some times at the end, depending on the tides or the exigencies of the work.

facts.text: Union claimed 12 hours shift should be 8 hours work and 4 hours overtime like Flotilla Crew.

anchor.surface_text: The Union claimed that a 12 hours shift should be divided into 8 hours work and 4 hours overtime as was the case with the Flotilla Crew. This claim was opposed by the Trustees.

facts.text: Trustees contended no breach of Minimum Wages Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to them, there was no breach of the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act. They contended that, regard being had to the number of actual work hours, the case of shore crew at the Princes and Victoria Docks and the Butcher Island could not be compared with that of the crew at the Alexandra Docks or the Flotilla Crew.

facts.text: Tribunal accepted the entire case of the Trustees.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accepted the entire case put forward on behalf of the Trustees and the Union has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Workmen come under the Schedule of the Minimum Wages Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the present workmen come under the Schedule. The hours of work and the payment of overtime are, therefore, governed by the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and the Minimum Wages Central Rules, 1950

facts.text: Alexandra Docks work on lock gates system, Princes and Victoria Docks are tidal.

anchor.surface_text: In explanation of this difference it may be pointed out that the Alexandra Docks work on a system of lock gates which enables the depth of water at the docks to be artificially regulated but the Princes and Victoria Docks, being tidal, work only at high tide.

facts.text: Flotilla Crew has 12 hours duty with 8 hours work and 4 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: The Flotilla Crew has to remain on duty for full 12 hours and they work as and when they are required. Although their hours of duty are only 8 they are entitled, if present for work, for overtime up to four hours.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the decision of the Tribunal is right and appeal fails.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right in the circumstances of this case. The appeal must therefore fail.
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 20, 1963 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference CG IT-25 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and the Minimum Wages Central Rules, 1950 and the controversy in this case must be appreciated and resolved in accordance with them. We shall now turn to these provisions. We are concerned with two sections and two rules. The sections are Nos. 13 and 14 and the rules Nos. 24 and 25.

concepts.interpretation: Section 13 authorises Government to fix number of hours constituting normal working day inclusive of specified intervals of rest; distinguishes hours of work from intervals of rest; normal working day up to 9 hours work spread over 12 hours with rest intervals specified beforehand.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: anye to the question of overtime. If work on any day is taken which goes beyond 9 hours the provisions of s. 14 apply. That action speaks of overtime.

concepts.unlisted_description: Fixing hours for normal working day, inclusive of intervals

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned with two sections and two rules. The sections are Nos. 13 and 14 and the rules Nos. 24 and 25. The whole of the matter in dispute admittedly is governed by these four provisions.

concepts.interpretation: Overtime payable for work in excess of 9 hours constituting normal working day, at double rate; does not apply to specified rest intervals.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 24. Number of hours of work which shall constitute a normal working day- The number of hours which shall constitute a normal working day shall be- a in the case of an adult, 9 hours, b in the case of a child, 41 hours. The working day of an adult worker shall be so arranged that inclusive of the intervals for rest, if any, it shall not spread over more than twelve hours on any day.

concepts.interpretation: 9 hours work for adult, spread over not more than 12 hours inclusive of rest intervals; distinguishes work hours from rest.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s during which the workman is on duty and inaction is due to want of work for him, but they must be pre-determined periods of inaction during which th

anchor.surface_text: Rule 25.Extra wages for overtime-- When a worker works in an employment for more than nine hours on any day or for more than forty-eight hours in any week, he shall, in respect of overtime work, be entitled to wages, ... at double the ordinary rate of wages.

concepts.interpretation: Double wages for overtime beyond 9 hours/day or 48/week; ordinary rate excludes bonus.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the hours of work in a six-day week shall number exceed 48, although on any particular day the hours of work in a day may go up to 9. In this indirect

anchor.surface_text: Nothing in this Act shall prejudice the operation of the provisions of section 59 of the Factories Act, 1948 in any case where those provisions are applicable.
54. Daily hours. Daily hours Subject to the provisions of section 51, no adult worker shall be required or allowed to work in a factory for more than nine hours in any day

concepts.interpretation: Comparison: similar to Min Wages, 9 hours max, spread over 10.5-12 hours.

anchor.surface_text: Intervals for rest. The periods of work of adult workers in a factory each day shall be so fixed that no period shall exceed five hours and that no worker shall work for more than five hours before he has had an interval for rest of at least half an hour.

concepts.interpretation: Requires rest interval after 5 hours unlike Min Wages; for comparison only.

anchor.surface_text: Spread over. The periods of work of an adult worker in a factory shall be so arranged that inclusive of his intervals for rest under section 55 they shall not spread over more than ten and a half hours in any day

concepts.interpretation: Spread over max 10.5 hours unlike 12 in Min Wages.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions of section 51, no adult worker shall be required or allowed to work in a factory for more than nine hours in any day

anchor.surface_text: The controversy in the present case is a narrow one. It is whether the fixing of a two hours rest and two hours overtime involves a breach of the two sections of the Act and the two rules quoted here ? The Minimum Wages Act was enacted to enable Government to fix minimum rates of wages in certain employments.

issues.text: S. 13 fixes the number of hours in a numbermal working day and this number is inclusive of one or more specified intervals. They read Rule 24, which prescribes a numbermal working day of 9 hours, as including within the 9 hours one or more intervals of rest.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the workmen is that S. 13 fixes the number of hours in a numbermal working day and this number is inclusive of one or more specified intervals. They read Rule 24, which prescribes a numbermal working day of 9 hours, as including within the 9 hours one or more intervals of rest. We do number think this is a companyrect reading either of s. 13 or of Rule 24.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 only authorises Government to fix the number of hours which shall constitute a normal working day, inclusive of one,- or more specified intervals. The normal working day thus includes a hours of actual duty, and b one or more specified intervals.

arguments.claim: Interval of rest means a break in work during which workman on duty but not called to display physical activity or sustained attention, if specified beforehand

anchor.surface_text: We now come to the question of overtime. If work on any day is taken which goes beyond 9 hours the provisions of s. 14 apply. That section speaks of overtime. Overtime is payable for work in excess of the number of hours constituting a normal working day.

arguments.claim: Variable recess permissible if specified in advance; Trustees not guilty of infraction by variable recess
No compulsion to break up hours of work with fixed rest intervals if nature of work (tides) prevents; recess fixed near middle as possible
Case of Princes/Victoria Docks shore crew cannot be compared to Alexandra Docks or Flotilla Crew due to different work

anchor.surface_text: The crew at the Princes and Victoria Docks work in a different way and their case cannot be compared with that of the Flotilla Crew or the crew at the Alexandra Docks. The Flotilla Crew has to remain on duty for full 12 hours

arguments.claim: Decision of Tribunal is right; appeal fails

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right in the circumstances of this case. The appeal must therefore fail.

holdings.text: The decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right and the appeal fails.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of 8h work + 2h specified variable rest + 2h OT complies with ss.13-14 and rr.24-25; distinguishes from other crews; variable rest permissible given tides.

holdings.text: The break-up of a 12 hours shift into 8 hours duty, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime does not offend the Minimum Wages Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 only authorises Government to fix the number of hours which shall constitute a normal working day, inclusive of one,- or more specified intervals. The normal working day thus includes a hours of actual duty, and b one or more specified intervals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.13 defines normal day as actual duty hours + specified rest intervals; r.24(1) fixes 9h work excl rest; r.24(2) spread <=12h incl rest; 8h work +2h rest =10h <12h, +2h OT for work.

holdings.text: Normal working day under s.13 includes hours of actual duty and one or more specified intervals of rest.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 only authorises Government to fix the number of hours which shall constitute a normal working day, inclusive of on,-. or more specified intervals. The normal working day thus includes a hours of actual duty, and b one or more specified intervals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.13(1)(a); intervals must be specified; distinguishes work from rest.

holdings.text: Interval of rest is a break in work during which workman is on duty but not called to display physical activity or sustained attention, if specified beforehand.

anchor.surface_text: By interval under s. 13 is obviously meant interval of rest and this is clear from Rule 24 2 . There is no definition of interval either in the Act or the Rules but the provisions of S. 13 2 c read with S. 13 3 give us an indication of what is meant by an interval

holdings.reasoning_summary: From s.13(2)(c),(3) re intermittent employment; rest = inaction on duty, not no work; must be pre-specified.

holdings.text: Rule 24 distinguishes hours of work (9h for adult) from intervals of rest; working day incl rest not spread over more than 12h.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus distinguished between period of work and interval of rest we may now turn to Rule 24 which prescribes the number of hours of work which is to constitute a normal working day. Sub-rule 1 a provides that the number of hours constituting a normal working

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heading 'hours of work'; sub-r(1) 9h work; sub-r(2) spread incl rest <=12h; rejects incl rest in 9h.

holdings.text: Overtime payable only for actual work in excess of 9 hours (normal working day); not for rest intervals.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.14: pay OT for work > normal day hours (9h per r.24); excludes specified rest.

holdings.text: Trustees not guilty of infraction by variable recess so long as specified in advance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rest must be specified beforehand; advance daily notice satisfies; tides make fixed impossible.

holdings.text: No compulsion to interpose fixed rest intervals if nature of work (tides) prevents; recess fixed near middle as possible.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No s.55 Factories Act equivalent requiring break after 5h; accommodates tidal work.

holdings.text: Shore crew at Princes/Victoria Docks cannot be compared to Alexandra Docks or Flotilla Crew.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Different work patterns: tidal vs lock gates vs flotilla full duty; justifies different OT/rest.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right in a circumstances of this case. The appeal must therefore fail.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal fails; decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal upheld as correct in the circumstances of the case
